(1/3) We are facing an unprecedented health and economic crisis in the coronavirus pandemic. With this bipartisan legislation, help is on the way. This legislation will provide significant and urgently needed help for our health care system, families and small businesses.

With all the stress this outbreak has brought, it’s important to be reminded of the good things that are happening—like our community’s ability to come together to help those in need.

Here are a few stories from home that have brightened my day.

The U.S. should be the leader on this. Other nations have evacuated their citizens from countries when travel has been restricted. 

I understand that this is not an easy task, but the federal government must do all it can to protect our citizens, no matter where they are.

This article is 4 days old and unfortunately, still relevant. Minnesotans are currently stranded across the globe because of this pandemic. I’ve been pressing the @StateDept to step in and protect our citizens.

My other bill would ensure that no person—with or without insurance—incurs cost-sharing when receiving a test to confirm a COVID-19 infection. Specifically, this bill waives cost-sharing for COVID-19 diagnostic testing and testing-related services—such as the cost of a visit.

One bill would prohibit employers from firing, punishing or otherwise discriminating against a worker who is quarantined or isolated—or who is caring for a family member in quarantine or isolation—amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
I will continue to work in Minnesota and Washington on the federal response to COVID-19. Yesterday I intro'd two bills to help contain and prevent spread of the virus.

With this in mind, I have directed the majority of my staff in our Minnesota and Washington DC offices to work from home. This decision has been made to protect the health our staff as well as the hundreds of Minnesotans who visit our offices every week.

As your Senator, my top priority as we respond to the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak is to help keep Minnesotans healthy. This is a serious public health event, and we all must work together to help stop the spread of this virus.

(3/3) Trump says anyone who wants a test can get a test. Not true. Top infectious disease doctor says our testing system is failing. Believe the doctor.

(2/3) Almost a week later the Trump administration can’t tell senators when we will have tests, how many, why we are weeks behind South Korea and Australia, and what the plan is to fix it. Worst I have seen, and it’s hurting people.
(1/3) Last week VP Pence told Congress the U.S. would have a million tests for coronavirus by Friday. That was untrue.

Tonight coming home my taxi driver told me how worried he was, and then he said, “we’re all in this together. I might be healthy, but if you’re sick, we’re in it together.”  I don’t think this is a concept Donald Trump has ever understood.

Trump has obstructed efforts to contain & suppress coronavirus & has misled ppl about how serious it is. Tonight—after weeks—he tells us the way to stop this “foreign virus” is to stop travel to Europe. Can’t imagine a worse example of leadership when our country needs it most.

Anne Mckeig is the first Native American justice to serve on the Minnesota Supreme Court. A descendant of White Earth Nation, Anne's a specialist and advocate for children's rights, previously serving as Assistant Attorney for Hennepin County of the child protection division. https://t.co/3tMFUscfhh

Nellie Stone Johnson was the 1st African American to hold office in Mpls. First serving on the Library Board in 1945, she launched a decades long political career. An expert on civil and social rights, Nellie became a friend & advisor to both Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale. https://t.co/Nl5h4QnQSF

Maria L. Sanford dedicated her life to education. She was the first female professor at @UMNews, a gifted speaker, and advocate for education. She is honored today by a statue in the U.S. Capitol and as the namesake for a residential hall at the U of M Twin Cities. https://t.co/xGB1IhNakh

Toni Stone was the first woman to play professional baseball. Raised in St. Paul, she signed with a semi-pro team at the age of 15 before she went on to play from 1949 to 1955. She is remembered for her skill in the infield that rivaled her male teammates’. https://t.co/sf7UNY5iXe

Coya Knutson was the first woman to represent Minnesota in Congress. She served two terms from 1955-1959. An advocate for farmers, she became the first woman to gain a seat on the Agriculture Committee where she fought to reform Eisenhower’s dated agricultural policies. https://t.co/Wi4ki5mYwU

For #InternationalWomensDay I am honoring some very important trailblazers. Their courage, leadership, and passion, have helped advance women towards equality. Join me as we celebrate five incredible women we are lucky to call Minnesotans.

There’s a proposal led by @SenSchumer that would give the Trump Administration ample funding to fight Coronavirus.

They should support it and stop taking away dollars meant to help folks who need heat in the dead of winter.

For those from states with cold winters, it’s obvious how awful this is but for those who need some context, it was 20 degrees BELOW zero last week in International Falls. 

Imagine not being able to pay to heat your home for your family in these conditions.

Trump wants to transfer tens of millions of dollars from a program that helps people, many of them seniors, afford heat during the winter.
 
Defunding this program—known as LIHEAP—has been a pet project of the Administration for years. I'm fighting so they don't get away with it. https://t.co/3cyJA2D6Hl

This virus is serious and requires a serious response. Trump’s team needs to pull themselves together and stop failing to take this seriously.

In the Senate cloakrooms we now have carefully labeled cubbies to put our phones, iPads and smart watches aside while we go onto the floor. You can tell it’s hard for some of us to leave them there.

Looking out at my colleagues, I was struck by how rare it is that we are all on the floor together, sitting down, and focused on one thing. What would the Senate be like if we came together like this more often?

Senate staff on both sides of the aisle made sure we all lined up to sign the oath in the correct order. That was the only time all day that Democrats and Republicans mixed in together. We need to mix more.
When Roberts came onto the floor the air changed. He looked, not pained, exactly, but as if he also felt the weight of history.

After lunch, the women were thinking logistics.
